#Text=BBC : Ethiopian famine aid ' siphoned off ' to buy weapons according to rebels , report
#Text=Friday , March 5 , 2010

#Text=According to a BBC report , funds raised for famine relief aid in Ethiopia , such as those raised by the Live Aid benefit concert pictured here , were " siphoned off " by rebels to buy weapons .
#Text=Image : Squelle .

#Text=An investigation by the BBC has revealed that millions of dollars in famine relief aid money , including the money raised from the charity supergroup Band Aid and the Live Aid concert held by Bob Geldof , was " siphoned off " by Ethiopian rebels to buy weapons .
#Text=One rebel said that at least US$ 95 million ( £63 million ) from — Western governments and private charities — was diverted into rebel coffers .

#Text=This was also noted in a declassified Central Intelligence Agency assessment of the famine situation titled Ethiopia : Political and Security Impact of the Drought , in which the report states , " Some funds that insurgent organizations are raising for relief operations , as a result of increased world publicity , are almost certainly being diverted for military purposes . "

column1: #Text=During the 1984 – 1985 famine , Ethiopia was fighting Eritrean and Tigray rebels in those two northern provinces , although Eritrea has since gained its independence .
#Text=Since the countryside was out of the government 's control , aid was brought in from neighboring Sudan .
#Text=Some aid came in the form of food , while other aid came as cash which would be used by the aid agencies to buy grain from Ethiopian farmers .
#Text=Rebels would disguise themselves as traders and merchants to get their hands on the currency . "

#Text=Peberdy disputes the claims that he was duped , saying ,  As far as we were concerned and as far as we were told by REST , the people we were dealing with were merchants . "

column1: #Text=He added , " It 's 25 years since this happened , and in the 25 years it 's the first time anybody has claimed such a thing . "
#Text=Meles Zenawi , the Prime Minister of Ethiopia since 1991 and chairman of the TPLF since 1985 .
#Text=Image : Helene C. Stikkel , Department of Defense .
#Text=However , an exiled TPLF commander who lives in the Netherlands , Aregawi Berhe , is backing Araya 's story .
#Text=He said the group got their hands on over US$ 100 million ( £66 million ) of which 95 % went to buy weapons and build up a hardliner Marxist party inside the rebel movement .
#Text=The remaining five percent would go to famine victims .
#Text=Berhe told the BBC that the group would put on a " drama " to get the money .
#Text=Berhe said , " The aid workers were fooled . "

#Text=In response to the allegations , the charity Christian Aid issued a statement saying , " There are allegations in the story which are against all of Christian Aid 's principles and our initial investigations do not correspond to the BBC 's version of events .
